properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY ISSUED FOR PRINCE GEORGE The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Prince George due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure to fine particulate matter is of particular concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce exposure to fine particulate matter. The City of Prince George’s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including back-yard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits recreational fires, use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users), and street sweeping activties (unless approved by an Authorized Person). Industry is required to follow permit requirements that are triggered during airquality advisories and are asked to reduce emissions wherever possible. Real-time airquality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-03T12:20:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-02T20:21:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1934221420.2019
Area: Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VANDERHOOF (December 2, 2019 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued an Air Quality Advisory for Vanderhoof because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected. Blizzard conditions will redevelop near the Richardson Mountains this morning as winds increase to easterly 80 km/h gusting to 100. Winds will ease by Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T04:26:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T12:27:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1126116591.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy with amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres is expected beginning Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds causing blowing snow at times, especially near the shoreline. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy is expected over the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula beginning near midday Tuesday then over the Lower North Shore late in the day. Snowfall amounts could reach and even exceed 15 centimetres by Wednesday morning. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds causing blowing snow locally. Driving conditions could be hazardous during this period. Motorists should alter their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Snow may become mixed with rain this afternoon then taper to a few flurries in the evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy mix of wintry weather expected on Tuesday. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: early Tuesday morning until late Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain are forecast to begin early Tuesday morning over southern New Brunswick. Precipitation will gradually change to rain later in the morning, with temperatures only expected to rise a degree or two above zero. Rain is then expected to change back to snow from west to east later Tuesday afternoon. This combination of messy precipitation could impact travel, especially Tuesday morning and again potentially late Tuesday afternoon. Snowfall and freezing rain warnings are in effect elsewhere in New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T06:47:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T14:48:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1200797480.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of significant freezing rain is expected Tuesday. Locations: central, western, southern and potentially eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday morning to overnight Tuesday night. Possible Freezing Rain: 5 to 15 mm. Remarks: Freezing rain will develop over the south coast of Newfoundland Tuesday morning and spread northward during the day. Along the coast, precipitation will quickly change to rain by afternoon. Most significant ice buildup will occur inland away from the coast. At this time, the duration and intensity of the freezing rain over eastern Newfoundland is quite uncertain. It is possible the bulk of the freezing precipitation will stay over the western half of the island. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-03T06:16:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T14:17:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1115453827.2019

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-12-03T12:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-12-02T12:05:47-06:00, 40E8AD58-6E5F-CF01-BC4D-72DD44B51C5B
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extended period of freezing rain and ice pellets expected on Tuesday. Locations: Kent county, Grand Lake and Queens county, Oromocto and Sunbury county and northern Charlotte county. Time span: early Tuesday morning until Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will develop early Tuesday morning then change quickly to ice pellets and freezing rain. Precipitation will gradually change back to snow from west to east on Tuesday afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Rigolet, Eagle River and Cartwright to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Possible snowfall: 10 to 20 cm except 5 to 10 cm for Rigolet, Upper Lake Melville and along the coast from Mary's Harbour to L'Anse-au-Clair. Remarks: Snow will begin in the Straits area Tuesday evening then spread to the rest of southeastern and central Labrador during the night. Areas along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Mary's Harbour are likely to see a change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain or drizzle overnight Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. This will limit the snowfall totals for these areas. It still appears that both Upper Lake Melville and Rigolet will be on the northwestern edge of the precipitation swath and are also less likely to see the higher snowfall amounts. Any shift in the storm's track could impact these snowfall totals so future forecasts should be monitored for any potential changes. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-03T11:53:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T19:54:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2829705876.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR COURTENAY (December 2, 2019 - Courtenay, BC) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Island Health is continuing an Air Quality Advisory for the Comox Valley because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for preganant women and infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-02T18:16:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1955540070.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of wintry weather expected on Tuesday. Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: early Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will develop early Tuesday morning and are expected to change to rain later in the morning over eastern areas and in the afternoon over western areas, with a risk of freezing rain during the changeover. This could impact travel, especially during the commute Tuesday morning. Rain showers will persist until Wednesday morning, when they will change over to flurries. In addition, higher than normal water levels will combine with rough and pounding surf along northeastern facing shores of Prince Edward Island on Tuesday, peaking near high tide on Tuesday afternoon and extending into the early evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of wintry weather expected with a potential prolonged period of freezing rain or ice pellets. Time span: Tonight until Wednesday morning. Locations: Nova Scotia, especially over inland areas. Remarks: Precipitation over southern and eastern parts of mainland Nova Scotia will spread very slowly northward tonight, reaching Cape Breton by early Tuesday morning. Areas near the Atlantic coast can expect rain, with a period of heavy rain on Tuesday, while inland areas of the province and the Annapolis Valley could receive a prolonged period of freezing rain or ice pellets tonight into Tuesday morning. This could impact travel, especially during the commute Tuesday morning. Indications show that warning criteria will not be met, however the public is advised to monitor future forecasts. In addition, higher than normal water levels combined with rough and pounding surf are expected along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia on Tuesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T11:14:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T19:15:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3195050329.2019
